content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good Clash, although definitely on the hardest end of the spectrum. In order to solve this clash, we must do all these steps in a short time:

- understand that the output is not a flow rate, but a ratio of a flow rate to the maximum flow rate
- guess that the total temperature is the weighted average of the two temperatures
- guess that the total flow is the sum of the two flows
- correctly express the problem as a linear system of 2 equations in 2 unknowns
- solve the linear system of equations
- understand that the "maximum flow rate" of a tap is not a constraint to be added to the equations (in fact, it is, but the tests and validators have been chosen so that this constraint can be ignored)
- need to understand how precisely to display the floating-point output (this is always harder than you think, especially on a speed contest like Clash of code!!)

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: it is good

I think this is actually really hard, especially since you give no hints.

I really struggled to come up with a solution while timing myself, despite having a physics background... I think it would be extremely hard for people who don't have one.

Some clashers may not even know the basic facts needed to solve this like that mixing two flows of water at different temperatures, the resultant water will have a flow equal to the sum of the two and a temperature equal to the weighted average (weighted by flows).

I'm not sure if this is a good clash, because the only way to make it fair is to give so many hints and explanations that it no longer works well as a problem...

It seems to me that this is more of a physics/algebra problem than a coding problem...

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Interesting mathematical problem, those with algebraic experience should face no issues. Would be a fun challenge to solve and could be done within the time constraints
Test 5 violates the second constraint (Ft = 5, Mc = 4, Ft is not ≤ Mc).

I managed to solve it in the end, but it relied on me writing out the algebra and just solving it step by step.

I initially tried to just brute force it by checking all flow values from 0.00 to 1.00 in 0.001 steps, but it failed for some tests.

# tt = (tc*fc+th*fh)/(fc+fh)
# ft = (fc+fh)
# fh = ft-fc
# tt = (tc*fc+th*ft-th*fc)/ft
# fc*(tc-th) = tt*ft-th*ft
# fc = (tt*ft-th*ft)/(tc-th)
fc = (tt*ft-th*ft)/(tc-th)
fh = ft - fc
puts "%.2f %.2f" % [(fc/mc*100).to_i/1e2, (fh/mh*100).to_i/1e2]

I undrestand what you say, but it is a simple system of 2 linear equations, that can be solved in a couple algebraic simplifications, and the solution is nothing really complex.
The hard part for some players might be to write the system. I guess I could add a hint to explain how to calculate the resultant flow and temperature (The resultant flow is the sum of the flows and the resultant flow×temperature is the sum of the flows×temperatures).
I'm not sure if I should keep it as a clash or make it a puzzle, but it seems quite simple to me, maybe too easy for an easy puzzle. Tell me waht you think.

I'm not sure why people think that there's a such thing as 'too easy' for a puzzle, I think it's fine to have Easy puzzles that are quite easy, it's great for beginner coders.

I think this is nicer as a puzzle, because it means that coders who don't know the physics can spend a bit of time researching the problem at their own pace and figuring out how to solve it.

As a clash, it will just be a case where people who know physics and algebra get 100% and then everyone else gets 0%, which is a bit sad when that happens.

I agree that once you know the equations it's not too hard, but currently you don't supply them.

If you supplied the equations then I think this could be an acceptable clash. (Note: I think it's better to just give the equations rather than explain them in words though, less confusing)
I added a (small) hint. If other people agree that it seems too hard for a clash, I'll resubmit it as an easy puzzle.
That hint helps a bit, but could definitely go further. I'd at least mention solving the algebra to make sure they get it, but up to you. :)

I tried to solve the equation on my side too and couldn't help but to check to the correction, on the first line of your equation, you're writing :
temp_target = (temp_cold*flow_cold + temp_hot*flow_hot)/(flow_cold + flow_hot)

I understand the numerator equation : weighted temps because of flow repartition but not the denominator ^^'. Is it because it should be seen as a pondered mean ?
temp_target = sum_of(value_n*coef_n)/sum_of(coef_n) where coef_n is a cold/hot flow

btw, using acronyms didn't helped understanding the problem while reading diagonally (what's everyone doing in Clash of Code honestly). it took me a big minute to understand what's supposed to mean Mc and Mh. Variable names like max_flow_cold, max_flow_hot would've helped.

Right, I have changed the variable names.
For the equation, you can maybe see it as :
flow_res * temp_res = flow_cold * temp_cold + flow_hot * temp_hot
Therefore : temp_res = (flow_cold * temp_cold + flow_hot * temp_hot) / flow_res
(And flow_res = flow_cold + flow_hot)
